title: Beta and nightly on playpen produce worse code for `clz` intrinsic compared to stable

labels.name: A-LLVM
labels.description: Area: Code generation parts specific to LLVM. Both correctness bugs and optimization-related issues.

body:
Consider the following code snippet (which calculates the number of binary digits of a `u32`):

```
pub fn ilog2(n: u32) -> u32 {
    // 1 + 31 ^ a = 32 - a for all values of a in [0, 32],
    // but neither LLVM nor gcc 4.8 produce optimal
    // code for the second expression.
    1 + 31 ^ n.leading_zeros()
}
```

This is what the assembly output looks like with optimizations turned on (on stable):

```
_ZN5ilog220h72c96f05204d06ebeaaE:
    .cfi_startproc
    bsrl    %edi, %ecx
    movl    $63, %eax
    cmovnel %ecx, %eax
    xorl    $63, %eax
    retq
```

(As you can see, only conditional instructions have been emitted instead of branches)

This is how the assembly output looks like with optimizations turned on (on beta and nightly):

```
_ZN5ilog220h72c96f05204d06ebeaaE:
    .cfi_startproc
    movl    $32, %eax
    testl   %edi, %edi
    je  .LBB0_2
    bsrl    %edi, %eax
    xorl    $31, %eax
.LBB0_2:
    xorl    $32, %eax
    retq
```

It looks to me like beta and nightly LLVM is being way too conservative regarding the `bsr` instruction (and assume it must never be invoked with an operand of 0, which is not true according to both Intel's and AMD's programmer's manuals).
